did.unittitle: Indiana University School of Music Early Music Institute records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Indiana University, Bloomington. School of Music. Early Music Institute.

did.abstract: The Early Music Institute was established as a part of the School of Music at Indiana University Bloomington in 1980, with Thomas Binkley serving as the founding director. The goal of the EMI was to address the needs of students who wanted to pursue studies and advanced degrees in professional performance of early music and collegium directing. Binkley and the EMI also established the Thomas Binkley Early Music Recordings Archive , which consisted of a vast array of sound recordings for the benefit of student performance and scholarship in early music. This collection consists of student, faculty, and project files and includes correspondence, files on curriculum development, events and publicity, and information on the development of the Thomas Binkley Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Select files are closed to researchers and are indicated in the finding aid. Most of the restricted files are student or faculty personnel files. All restricted files are listed where they would fall in the intellectual organization of the collection but are physically stored at the end of the collection (Box 5-8).
Advance notice is required for access.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Early Music Institute (EMI) was formally established as a part of the Indiana University School of Music in 1980. The EMI was created to address the needs of students who wanted to pursue studies and increase their experience in professional performance of early music. The EMI focused on the study of performance on musical instruments from the medieval, renaissance, and baroque periods. Today, the EMI continues to thrive and currently offers degrees at the undergraduate and graduate level.

Thomas Binkley was appointed Professor of Music at Indiana University in 1979. He founded the institute shortly thereafter, and was director of the Institute until January 1995. Previously, Binkley had been the director of the Studio der Fruhen Musik in Munich, Germany from 1957-1979. He had also been a teacher and performer in the Medieval Program at the Schola Cantorum Basiliensis in Basel, Switzerland. During his tenure, Prof. Binkley founded the commercial record label, Focus Records. These recordings consisted of faculty performances and EMI ensemble performances. He also published articles and reviews in various professional journals on such topics as performance practice. In addition, he established the Archive of Early Music Recordings in 1989, which was later renamed The Thomas Binkley Early Music Recordings Archive. Binkley felt an archive of sound recordings was necessary as a research tool in the field of musical performance and especially for the field of early music revival.

Binkley died in April 1995. Wendy Gillespie served as Interim Director until Paul Hillier became Director of the Early Music Institute in 1996. Hillier maintained the position until 2003, at which time Wendy Gillespie again was appointed as the Interim Director a position she held until Michael McCraw appointment in 2005.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into six series: Administrative files, Curriculum, Events, Faculty, Students, and Thomas Binkley Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Early Music Institute records span the period from 1972 to 2001 with the bulk of the material created during the period from 1980 to 2000. Since it was found that the records overlapped in their use and function between directors of the EMI, this collection combines the records of Thomas Binkley's entire tenure and over half of Paul Hillier's tenure. The collection contains six series: Administrative files, Curriculum, Events, Faculty, Students, and Thomas Binkley Archives.

The first series contains Administrative files for the period 1978-2000 and consists of five sub-series: Correspondence, Financial records, Instruments, Newsletter, Recruitment and Orientation, and Technology and Equipment. Correspondence contains fan letters to the EMI, administrative memoranda, and address lists. Prominent correspondents include Adelheid M. Gealt, Indiana University Art Museum Director; Dr. Cleveland Johnson, Professor of Music at DePauw University; and Dr. Roger Cody, Professor of Music at Truman State University (formerly Northeast Missouri State University). Financial records consist of files on purchasing insurance, arranging accommodations for faculty retreats, printing budgets, and reporting financial assets and expenses. The sub-series entitled Instruments consist of records documenting instrument purchases, requests, and inventories. The sub-series Newsletter consists of mailing lists, the first volume of the EMI department newsletter, and correspondence relating to production and contents of the Newsletter. The sub-series Recruitment and Orientation contains advertisements for the School of Music and Early Music Program as well as new faculty and student information packets. All sub-series are arranged alphabetically.

The Curriculum series, 1977-2000, is arranged into three sub-series: Courses, Development and Policies, and Programs and Workshops. Courses includes IU Bulletins as well as files containing course schedules and memos concerning the best times, locations, and instructors for different Music School classes. It also contains files on specific courses, such as F450 Chamber Music and X060 Baroque Orchestra, Concentus Ensemble, and Pro Arte. Courses files that are restricted include sensitive information such as rosters of students enrolled in various courses and student social security numbers. One file contains class notes and a sample sheet of music on transparency for instruction. The sub-series Development and Policy contains files on changes to degree programs, the creation of doctoral minors and certificates of study, and on the development of policies on administration and recitals. Programs and Workshops contains files on programs and workshops attended and provided by the EMI faculty, staff, and students, such as the Grant Writing Seminar and the Recorder Pedagogy Program. All sub-series are arranged alphabetically.

The Events series, 1979-2000, is arranged into three sub-series: Calendars and Publicity, Performances, and Repertory. Calendars and Publicity consists of schedules of events, news releases, and publicity items. Performances consists of files on the various events at which EMI ensembles performed, such as madrigal dinners, concerts, recitals, and operas. Repertory contains lists of pieces performed at various events, for chamber pieces, ensembles, and operas and ballets. All sub-series are arranged alphabetically.

The Faculty series spans the years 1972-2001. The series is further arranged into five sub-series, although the bulk of the files are restricted as they contain personnel information. The sub-series are Committees and Minutes, Faculty Files, Press and Projects, Sabbatical Replacements, and Visiting Faculty. Committees and Minutes consists of files related to the Hearing Committees for student recitals, Faculty Advisory Committees, and the EMI Personnel Task Force, and minutes from faculty meetings and the School of Music Council. Faculty Files include files pertaining to all or most faculty members of EMI, such as Thomas Binkley's memorial service and faculty discographies. This sub-series also includes data on faculty course loads per semester, and on issues relating to studio and teaching space. Press and Projects consists of records on various recording and press projects, such as the audio tour proposal and IU press contracts, conducted by or in conjunction with EMI faculty. The sub-series Sabbatical Replacements includes files on specific instructors on sabbatical and their replacement instructors. Visiting Faculty contains files on important figures in both the professional and academic worlds of early music that visited and taught at IU, either by request of the Patten Foundation or the Early Music Institute. It also contains files for the faculty/professional organization Harmonia, including a funding proposal for the organization. All sub-series are arranged alphabetically. The following sub-series are restricted, except for those files noted as unrestricted files, due to the private nature of the information included: Faculty Files, Sabbatical Replacements, and Visiting Faculty. The restricted files are stored at the end of the collection.

The Students series, 1983-2000, is arranged in five sub-series: Admissions, Assistant Instructorships and Graduate Assistantships, Evaluations, Financial Aid and Student Files. Admissions includes records on prospective student, including information on auditions and correspondence to and from the students. Assistant Instructorships and Graduate Assistantships contains files on rules and procedures for AI's and GA's as well as lists of which students received these appointments. The sub-series Evaluations contains exams and tests, recitals, and student papers. Financial Aid consists of files on what financial aid packages were awarded and to whom. Student Files includes individual student files. It also contain records about Estonian students and information on exchange programs and the organization Gamma Ut. The Gamma Ut file includes suggestions of topics for faculty lectures and minutes of a meeting. Restricted student files include admissions files, evaluations, financial aid data, and files of individual students, and are stored at the end of the collection with other restricted materials. All sub-series are arranged alphabetically.

The Thomas Binkley Archives, 1989-1996, contains files on the creation of the archives. The series is arranged alphabetically. Files include lists of the archives' holdings, project information, and technological information relating to the catalog and automated backup systems.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Photographs from the collection have been pulled and stored separately. Please contact the University Archives staff if you would like to view the photographic materials pulled from this collection:

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records such as newsletters, annual reports, bulletins, and publications may be accessed in the Archives of Institutional Memory
Archived web sites for the Institute may be included in Archive-It
Related photographs may be available in the University Archives Photographs Database

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyrights for records originating with Indiana University administrative units, departments, and other offices are held by the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Indiana University School of Music Early Music Institute records, Collection C294, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Transferred from Wendy Gillespie, Early Music Institute, April 2005.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Serena Olson and Sharity Nelson.
